Topic.Title: Oh no say it isn't so!

Message.Msg: ...“Again, there is no proof of man made global warming…I simply blew holes in your off topic nonsense.” – carolharold Speaking of off topic nonsense…whatever, or whomever for that matter, you are blowing, has absolutely no relevancy to the veracity of the scientific community’s opinion that global warming is real and a result of man’s activities. Obviously, the main thing you are blowing is hot air for the carbon based fuel industry. “…in fact about 97 percent of American scientists say that climate change is happening…” That’s ninety-seven percent, carol! If you are here simply to argue that 97% is not 100%, that’s a foolish and weak argument. If you, on the other hand, are here to argue that 97% equates to “no proof of man-made global warming”, you go well beyond looking foolish. You then fall into the category of those trying to deceive the public for the benefit of the special interests who benefit by causing the climate change…and for that, your children’s children will suffer, and you should be very ashamed. Pimping for the fossil fuel industry is not blowing holes in the scientific community by any stretch of the imagination. Climate Change: Public Skeptical, Scientists Sure By Richard Harris, NPR, 2011 The American public is less likely to believe in global warming than it was just five years ago. Yet, paradoxically, scientists are more confident than ever that climate change is real and caused largely by human activities. Something a bit strange is happening with public opinion and climate change. Anthony Leiserowitz, who directs the Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, delved into this in a recent poll. He not only asked citizens what they thought of climate change, he also asked them to estimate how climate scientists feel about global warming. ‘Only 13 percent of Americans got the correct answer, which is that in fact about 97 percent of American scientists say that climate change is happening, and about a third of Americans just simply say they don't know,’ he said. Most Americans are unaware that the National Academy of Sciences, known for its cautious and even-handed reviews of the state of science, is firmly on board with climate change. It has been for years Ralph Cicerone, president of the National Academy, paraphrased its most recent report on the subject. ‘The consensus statement is that climate changes are being observed, are certainly real, they seem to be increasing, and that humans are mostly likely the cause of all or most of these changes,’ he said. That's not just the view of the U.S. National Academies. There's also a consensus statement from the presidents of science academies from around the world, including the academies of China, the United Kingdom, India, Japan, Russia, France, Brazil, the list goes on.”

Only because my Yahoo daily posting email alerts displays the first few sentences of your intelligent response, did i read rest of what you wrote yesterday. My posting was directed to a Troller who said (in essence) the underfunding was so serious that retiree's would be left holding the bag. I think the idiot who wrote that got the JCP board confused with T. Sadly, that dimwit does not not know about insurance and safeguards that protects things like that from happening. I'm not here to spread nonsense like he and his ilk do. You and I are on the same page regarding the sustainability of not only the pension, but the excellent dividend we enjoy. Sorry again for the misunderstanding. Looking forward to a good earnings report later today and continued price appreciation.

Topic.Title: Oh no say it isn't so!

Message.Msg: "It is you with the off topic nonsense" Me? And here I thought I was responding to you and Froggie. "Wouldn't the ENTIRE community include 100% of such scientists?" I don't care. Jesus. The scientific community has reached a broad scientific consensus. If you don't know what a scientific consensus is or how it is reached, look it up. But you are arguing with the collective judgement of the entire scientific community. No one's been left out. Everyone's done their research and had their say. Just about every major scientific organization has issued a statement supporting the conclusion that global warming is real and it is man-made. Even the American Association of Petroleum Geologists has withdrawn its dissent. That is who you are arguing with. The entire scientific community. Not me.

Topic.Title: Oh no say it isn't so!

Message.Msg: So all this arguing about the scientific community and you don't care because, in your opinion, the state of medicine (which is not a science) has not advanced since blood-letting? Gee, somebody better tell NASA to cancel those missions because the world is flat! I don't know what to tell you except I am concerned about the state of STEM education in this country. The scientific method is what rid us of unscientific beliefs like blood-letting. The reason you use electric cars is because the internal combustion engine is inefficient at producing energy and at reducing pollutants. Big power plants are much more efficient. Plus, electric cars can recycle energy lost through braking and other sources (which is what makes hybrids so efficient). Ethanol is not a particularly superior energy source, but not for the reasons you mentioned. You have to burn oil and coal too, so what's the difference? The difference is oil & coal are fossil fuels made up entirely of stored carbon. Ethanol is made from living plants. When you get more oil, you are releasing alot of stored carbon. When you get more ethanol you are recycling carbon already in the atmosphere. Whatever you return to the atmosphere is carbon you already removed from the atmosphere. Understand?

Message.Title: Oh what a web we weave...
Message.Msg: Just out today an interim congressional report regarding the administrations bungling and subsequent cover up of events prior, during and after the murder of American citizens on September 11, 2012 in Benghazi, Libya. The primary findings include the following: o Reductions of security levels prior to the attacks in Benghazi were approved at the highest levels of the State Department, up to and including Secretary Clinton. This fact contradicts her testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on January 23, 2013. o In the days following the attacks, White House and senior State Department officials altered accurate talking points drafted by the Intelligence Community in order to protect the State Department. o Contrary to Administration rhetoric, the talking points were not edited to protect classified information. Concern for classified information is never mentioned in email traffic among senior Administration officials. o The Administration willfully perpetuated a deliberately misleading and incomplete narrative that the attacks evolved from a political demonstration caused by a YouTube video. IMHO, on one hand you have to hand it to the administration for its ability to stonewall, obfuscate and misrepresent the facts during a presidential campaign, but on the other, there may be some Americans left who, when they find out the truth, may have some uneasy feelings about an administration that through its actions willfully facilitated the deaths of a US Ambassador and three other American citizens, and then covered up the whole affair through stonewalling and deception. As Hillary was so famous to say "who cares...?" To be honest, I don't really know anymore. "In your heart you know he is right." The Frogg
